Award.AwardTitle: Lattice Field Theory and Hadronic Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Numerical studies of non-abelian gauge theories coupled to fermions in different representations of the gauge group will form the central focus of all projects in this proposal. Quantum chromodynamics (QCD) belongs to the class of theories we will investigate. The aim is to understand confinement and chiral symmetry breaking, the two features that help understand mass generation and much of the low energy non-perturbative aspects of these theories. We will consider the SU(N) gauge group and consider the limit of a large number of colors (N). We will couple the gauge theory to quarks in the adjoint representation. Using a phenomenon called reduction, we will be able to numerically study the theory on a single site lattice with the number of quark flavors extended to take on any real value. This will enable us to study conformal and near-conformal theories and help us understand mass generation. The de-confinement transition in QCD is currently under intense experimental investigation and we will study the role of baryonic chemical potential in the large-N limit of QCD. Two-dimensional fermion will be used as a probe to study the strong to weak coupling transition in the large N limit of QCD-like theories. We will study the effect of quark masses in multi-favor QCD and, in particular, consider the case of negative quark masses with the aim of identifying a curve in the space of mass parameters where one has massless pions.


Quarks carry a color charge and nuclear matter is formed from the binding of colored quarks mediated by gluons. Quantum chromodynamics (QCD) is the theory that describes the interaction of these color charges. Experiments have shown that quarks come in three colors but all nuclear matter is color neutral. Massless quarks and gluons give rise to nuclear matter that has mass. An understanding of this mass generation is of fundamental importance and this project will address various approaches to this problem by focusing on QCD-like theories in the limit of large number of colors. Such theories are closely related to recent developments in string theory and we will be able to make connections between field theory and string theory. The scientific methods involve analytical calculations and numerical computations. A post-doctoral fellow with prior experience in this area during his/her recent graduate work will be mentored by the PI to work on several aspects of the proposal. Computer clusters will be used for numerical computations and the results obtained as part of this proposal will be presented at international conferences in nuclear and particle physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Quantum Chromo Dynamics (QCD) is a well tested theory of strong interactions between gluons  (color degrees of freedom) and quarks (matter that has color) that describes sub-nuclear physics (baryons and mesons). Taken in isolation; it is an extremely beautiful theory — it has no free parameters and yet it contains an infinite number of massive particles in its spectrum. QCD belongs to a class of theories referred to as vector gauge theories with massless quarks and it has counterparts in two and three dimensions. The primary aim of this NSF project is to explore non-abelian (gluons) and abelian (photons) theories with massless quarks in two, three and four dimensions with the aim of understanding why some theories develop a scale and contain a large number of massive particles in their spectrum whereas other theories are scale invariant. 

 

Four dimensional non-abelian theories in the limit of large number of colors with massless quarks in the adjoint representation of the color group were studied. The attraction was a possible numerical ease in studying such theories — they reduce to what is referred to as matrix models. In spite of this simplification, the numerical study ended up being difficult due to the nature of these theories. Attempts to study the running of the coupling to demonstrate the presence of a scale resulted in evidence for non-analytic behavior. This suggested that it is necessary to explore parameters of the theory beyond numerical means to establish the precise nature of the theory.

 

A realization that confinement (presence of a scale in the gluon sector) and chiral condensate (presence of a scale in the matter sector) are tied together in QCD, motivates studies of theories in two dimensions. Two dimensional non-abelian gauge theories without any matter is known to be confining and is a string theory. Using a Hamiltonian formalism and separation into states with fixed baryon number, it was shown that the matter sector also develops a scale and there is a large number of particles with masses. Like in four dimensional QCD, this theory has baryons and mesons. The spectrum showed a behavior that was qualitatively similar to four dimensional QCD. For example, there were stronger interactions between the quarks inside baryons compared to the quarks inside mesons. Where as this provides an understanding of theories that develop a scale, a study of theories without a scale was still lacking.

 

Noting that parity plays the role of chiral symmetry in three dimensions, it is interesting to explore three dimensional abelian gauge theories with parity invariant quarks (QED in there dimensions). These theories were known to be scale invariant when one has large number of quark flavors. The theory was expected to develop a scale if the number of quark flavors were small. Using numerical investigation it was shown that the theory with even one flavor of parity invariant quark does not develop a scale. This result comes as a surprise since theories with one and two flavors of quarks are relevant in condensed matter physics for studying strongly coupled electrons and it has direct experimental relevance. A  continued exploration of this particular theory established that there are no massless particles in the scalar or vector sector of the theory further demonstrating the scale invariance of the theory. By extending the analysis to non-abelian gauge theories one expects to find theories in the plane of number of colors and flavors where scale invariance was broken. It was numerically demonstrated this is indeed the case in the limit of large number of colors for small number of flavors.
